qas.question: What ancient religious document exists in two versions and includes Old Iranian language?
What is the contemporary name of the religion which Avesta was part of?
What language shows a level of maturity corresponding to Old Avestan?
What language shows the same level of development as Younger Avestan?
What dialect is the Avesta language from?
How many dialects of the Avesta language or there?
What religion is vohu daena the contemporary name for?

plausible_answers.text: its use as a sacred language

qas.question: Why did old Persian retained its old characteristics long after the old Iranian languages
What language shows the same level of development as old Avestan

context: The other directly attested <b4_0>Old Iranian<b4_0/> dialects are the two forms of <a0_0>Avestan<a0_0/>, which take their name from their use in the <b6_0>Avesta<b6_0/>, the liturgical texts of indigenous Iranian religion that now goes by the name of <a1_0>Zoroastrianism<a1_0/> but in the Avesta itself is simply known as vohu daena (later: behdin). The language of the Avesta is subdivided into <b5_0>two dialects<b5_0/>, conventionally known as "Old (or 'Gathic') Avestan", and "Younger Avestan". These terms, which date to the 19th century, are slightly misleading since 'Younger Avestan' is not only much younger than 'Old Avestan', but also from a different geographic region. The Old Avestan dialect is very archaic, and at roughly the same stage of development as <a2_0>Rigvedic Sanskrit<a2_0/>. On the other hand, Younger Avestan is at about the same linguistic stage as <a3_0>Old Persian<a3_0/>, but by virtue of <b7_0>its use as a sacred language<b7_0/> retained its "old" characteristics long after the Old Iranian languages had yielded to their Middle Iranian stage. Unlike <b8_0>Old Persian<b8_0/>, which has Middle Persian as its known successor, Avestan has no clearly identifiable Middle Iranian stage (the effect of Middle Iranian is indistinguishable from effects due to other causes).
